title: NASA reveals stunning HD photo of rare 'red sprite' lightning
text:

While red sprite lightning has been recorded on Earth for over 30 years, the strange bursts of light remain one of the most mysterious types of lightning.

Now, NASA has revealed a stunning HD photo of a rare red sprite, showing the lightning in unbelievable detail.

The photo, which was snapped by photographer Stephanie Vetter, has been featured as NASA’s Astronomy Picture of the Day.

NASA explained: “Even though sprites have been recorded for over 30 years, their root cause remains unknown. Some thunderstorms have them, but most don't.

(Image: Hung-Hsi Chang)

“These mysterious bursts of light in the upper atmosphere momentarily resemble gigantic jellyfish.”

Red sprites are electrical bursts of light that often occur above thunderstorms.

As their name suggests, red sprites appear red at higher altitudes, but fade to blue at lower heights.

NASA added: “One unusual feature of sprites is that they are relatively cold - they operate more like long fluorescent light tubes than hot compact light bulbs.

“In general, red sprites take only a fraction of a second to occur and are best seen when powerful thunderstorms are visible from the side.”

This isn't the first time that NASA has featured a photo of lightning as its Astronomy Picture of the Day.

Last month, the space agency featured a beautiful lightning display captured by photogrpher Hung-Hsi Chang on board a plane travelling from Munich to Singapore.
